title: Portland closure would be another shock to the energy sector
text:
Some energy experts argued the smelter provided an effective balance in evening out the "duck curve" - where the wholesale electricity market prices are hollowed out courtesy of the influx of renewable energy such as wind and solar in the middle of the day.

Big industrial users and coal-fired power stations go hand-in-hand.

However, one thing is clear - if the Portland smelter does close it will have a domino effect on older coal-fired power stations in the NEM, including EnergyAustralia's Yallourn which was due to shut in 2032.

EnergyAustralia chief executive Catherine Tanna told The Australian Financial Review National Energy Summit in Sydney last week the timing of Yallourn's closure could be affected by "other factors".

She was alluding to the Victorian government's ambitious 50 per cent renewable policy which is challenging the profitability of older coal-fired power stations.

But she was also talking about the future of the Portland smelter.

"It's great proof of what we don't have control over. I don't think any of the power station owners or operators in this room today have any control over whether large demand loads disappear," she told the summit.

"This is a great example of something that is outside our control that could potentially change the closure date for a large coal-fired power generator."

Advertisement

But other energy observers believe the closure of the Portland smelter is long overdue and will in fact relieve a bit of pressure on the energy grid in south-eastern Australia.

It could help buy the market operator some time in firming up reserves, removing some demand from the grid and allow any excess supply to be moved across the border into NSW during times of peak demand.

It would also make it easier for Victorian Energy Minister Lily D'Ambrosio to reach the Labor government's 50 per cent renewable energy target.

The Portland smelter is no doubt on life support and may yet be saved by other rescue package from the Victorian or federal governments.

The existing $240 million in subsidies to keep the Portland smelter open - which expire in 15 months - allowed AGL Energy to sign a four-year supply deal with the smelter which runs out in 2021.

The smelter, which employs 600 people, has been subsidised in some form or another since 1988.

It once again raises the question about whether Australia should remain in energy intensive industries such as smelters, especially when they are struggling to stay afloat.

Australia's dramatic rise in power prices over the past decade has made it even harder for us to compete internationally.

And the reality remains large smelters are a major drain on the power grid - not to mention big carbon emitters. When black-outs threatened NSW a few years ago, the Tomago smelter - which uses 25 per cent of the state's power supply - was asked to turn off production just to keep the lights on.

The electricity grid may be changing before our eyes courtesy of the surge in renewable energy as we attempt to move towards a low-emissions economy. The closure of smelters, such as Portland, might just end up being the price of reaching those emission reduction targets.
description: The possible closure of Portland aluminium smelter in Victoria is another crunch point for the energy market and economy.
